Comment: I had white pieces and started with d4.
d5 was my friend's response.
e4, blackmar diemer gambit.
black accepts the gambit pawn.
Nc3, white is trying to get the pawn back.
Nf6 is a very sensible move, develops the knight and defend the pawn.
f3 challenging black pawn.
exf3, black wants to maintain the material advantage.
normally white would capture with knight, Qxf3 leaves the d4 pawn unprotected, but white is actually setting up the trap, d4 pawn is the bait.
my friend was a bit greedy and took the bait.
Be3 develops the dsb, also attacks black queen.

Qd8 looks embarrassing, but that would be a better move than the move played in the game, which is Qb4, attacks the b2 pawn. it seems like white can't castle queen side, because O-O-O results in Bg4, skewers the queen and the rook on d1.
O-O-O was played anyway.
Here comes the skewer! is white in trouble now, maybe my friend thought I would resign after this move.
Nb5 was played! Did white commit suicide? Not really! Can you see black's problem? if black captures the queen, then Nxc7# !
Black actually saw the problem, and played e6, now Nxc7 won't be mate.
Qxb7
my friend realized he was in trouble, Qe4, protects the rook on a8, also hopes queen exchange.
No thanks, no queen exchange for you my friend, Nxc7+
Ke7 is the only move
